awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrated Biorefinery for Pyrolysis Biofuels and Biotemplated Nanomaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
As the world?s population and energy demands increase, our global reliance on fossil fuel resources to provide this energy puts an incredible strain on the environment. The modern biorefinery could produce sustainable energy by converting lignocellulosic biomass to fuels through thermal and chemical routes. However, one of the primary issues with using pyrolysis (heating in the absence of oxygen) as a thermochemical conversion technique is the need for significant fuel upgrading to improve stability and increase the heating value of the oil. Though bio-oils can be upgraded post-production, current methods suffer from catalyst poisoning and high materials and operation costs. This research project aims to address these issues by incorporating inorganic compounds, such as metal nitrates and acetates into cellulosic feedstocks, to simultaneously engineer high-value nanomaterials via bio-templating and catalytically upgrade pyrolysis bio-oils, thus reducing the need for costly downstream upgrading. Using machine learning based techniques, such as materials informatics for potential catalyst selection and statistical design of experiments, to inform process variable decisions, the proposed work will add to a fundamental body of knowledge on in situ upgrading of thermochemically derived biofuels while offering a new paradigm in computationally informed, experimentally verified renewable fuel design.

The proposed research will focus on upgrading of biofuels during pyrolysis by simultaneously making bio-templated nanoparticles. Materials Informatics approaches will be used to select in situ pyrolysis catalysts and surrogate reactions will be used to predict (and then validate via integrated feedback loop) potential reaction pathways and formed nanomaterial structure.  By developing a new Pyrolysis Product Index that looks at where, for example, oxygen goes during pyrolysis, and how yields of marker compounds change upon catalyst incorporation, the principal investigators aim to synthesize a new way to discuss biofuel upgrading pathways, helping to standardize what is a rather diverse literature in terms of what is deemed to be a good pathway. The project also aims to elucidate the physical changes occurring during pyrolysis of metal-impregnated biomass using in operando Raman spectroscopy through an international collaboration with a group from Queens Mary University (United Kingdom). The objective is to improve our knowledge of which reaction pathways are most critical to devolatilization, and how to better design catalysts to improve both primary pyrolysis and to limit secondary reactions, such as re-condensation, and to promote cracking, thereby reducing tar formation. The proposed work also involves nanomaterials characterization to understand the process variables impacting size, morphology and crystallinity of bio-templated nanomaterials.  Advances in fundamental science stemming from the proposed work may lead to the design of an optimized integrated biorefinery to convert renewable sources to energy and materials. In addition to training graduate and undergraduate students in research, there ae plans to engage and mentor underrepresented students and develop and international graduate student exchange between Cornell, Boston and Queen Mary Universities. An active learning module for renewable energy applications will be developed, implemented and assessed in the three participating universities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

por.por_cntn:
Pyrolysis biofuels are formed when biomass is heated in an inert (no oxygen) atmosphere, such that the volatile compounds present leave the biomass and recondense as a liquid bio-oil. The oils produced from this process are too acidic and viscous to be used directly in transportation fleets but can be upgraded downstream in an energy-intensive process that often relies on rare earth catalysts. This innovative work demonstrated that inexpensive, abundant transition metals like copper and manganese can be used as catalysts when mixed with the biomass or placed directly downstream to upgrade pyrolysis vapors.

 We used materials informatics (MI) to identify the transition metal (TM) catalysts that promote cellulose devolatilization, deoxygenation and tar reduction to reduce the energy requirements of this process. We found, despite claims about the promise of MI, that existing “Big Data” databases are missing key information to truly enable such work. This is because the field does not publish studies with “poor” results – catalysts that are not catalytically active – leaving an incomplete picture in the literature. However, our experiments demonstrated that using these transition metal catalysts during pyrolysis either in situ (added directly to the biomass) or ex situ (directly downstream supported on an alumina substrate acting on the pyrolysis vapors), the quality of the bio-oil can be improved by removing oxygen from the oil and sending it to the gas phase. For example, four transition metals (Cu, Mn, Ni, Zn) were either wet impregnated into cherry pit biomass or impregnated on alumina wool fibers then placed downstream of the biomass to act on the devolatilized gases. The in situ catalysts Cu, Mn and Zn increase the pyrolysis bio-oil yield. The Mn, Ni and Zn used as ex situ catalysts increase the total non-condensable gas produced (e.g., hydrogen, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide), suggesting that these downstream catalysts crack the pyrolyzed molecules into smaller organics and water. The ex situ catalysts result in larger quantities of especially oxygen-containing gases like CO2, which in turn lowered the bio-oil’s oxygen content. However, such reactions also increase the water content of the resulting bio-oil, requiring additional separation. Both Mn and Zn used in either location enhance the concentration of alcohols relative to aromatic carbons, and when used ex situ, Mn shows a decrease in the ratio of aromatic to aliphatic carbon content.

 Over four years, three PhD students, one MS student, two undergraduates and one post-doctoral scholar have been trained through this work. Of these, the PhD student is now working at a large company developing processes for sustainable aviation fuels, the MS student at an environmental remediation firm, and one undergraduate is in the processing of applying to graduate school. The COVID-19 pandemic, and Cornell’s shift to online learning, opened new opportunities to incorporate research into the PI’s Introduction to Environmental Engineering Course. Over a series of pre-recorded videos, the PI introduced concepts about biomass to biofuel conversions, the need for inexpensive upgrading techniques, and about laboratory research in general. In-class Zoom discussions showed students gravitated towards these concepts and were able to grasp more difficult mass and energy balance concepts through the lens of this research than in years past. Post-COVID we integrated the pre-recorded video content and expanded in-class (in person) discussions concerning the research results as they unfolded throughout the project life.

 


Last Modified: 09/25/2023
Modified by: Jillian L Goldfarb
